title-group.article-title: Effect of functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes on the curing behavior and thermal stability of epoxy resin

article-meta.aff: 1College of Chemistry Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, P.R.China
2College of Material Science & Technology, Nanjing University of Aeronautics & Astronautics, Nanjing, P.R.China

author-notes.corresp: Fang Wang College of Chemistry Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, P.R.China Email: wangfangnuaa@yahoo.com.cn

abstract.p: Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) were modified by triethlene-tetramine (TETA) in order to attain better dispersibility and stronger interfacial bonding between MWNTs and epoxy matrix. The influence of surface treated MWNTs on the cure behavior of the diglycidyl ether of bisphenol A (DGEBA)/2-ethyl-4-methyl imidazole (EMI-2,4) system was investigated with nonisothermal differential scanning calorimetry. It was found that the curing peak temperature (T P) decreased with the addition of TETA-MWNTs. The curing apparent activation energy (E a) was calculated through Kissinger method. In addition, the thermal behavior of TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA/EMI-2,4 was examined by thermogravimetric analysis, and the result showed the addition of TETA-MWNTs could increase the thermal decomposition onset temperature (T B) and the degradation peak temperature (T max) of the nanocomposites. Scanning electron microscopy images of fractured surface of MWNTs/epoxy indicated homogeneous dispersibility of TETA-MWNTs and strong interfacial adhesion between the TETA-MWNTs and the epoxy matrix in the nanocomposites.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Since the discovery of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in 1991, they have inspired scientists to consider them for a range of potential applications and have become one of the most promising fillers for reinforcement of multi-functional nanocomposites. 1
–4 Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) have unique structure and superior physical properties such as excellent thermal and electrical conductivities, high stiffness and strength, low density, a large specific surface area and high chemical stability. 5 –7 The introduction of MWNTs as a structure element in nanocomposites should improve the material properties and therefore a large variety of applications, such as microcircuit wiring, sensors, field emission displays, artificial muscles and hydrogen storage, have already been demonstrated. 8,9 Especially carbon nanotubes have shown a high potential to improve the material properties of polymers. Epoxy resin is one of the most important thermoset polymers and has been wildly used because of its excellent performance. 10 –12 Using MWNTs as the reinforcement of epoxy nanocomposites can widen their use in potential applications such as advanced composite materials, adhesives, coatings, encapsulates, liquid crystal display, etc.

The potentials of employing MWNTs as reinforcements have been severely limited because of the difficulties associated with dispersion of entangled MWNTs during processing and the poor interfacial interactions between MWNTs and the polymer. Therefore, chemical modification of the surface of carbon nanotubes and good dispersion of MWNTs are required for the applications of the nanocomposites. 13,14 Several studies have suggested that the properties can be improved even further if better dispersions and more efficient load transfer can be achieved. 15
–18 In addition, it is very important to investigate their cure behaviors of MWNTs/epoxy composites on the excellent physical properties. 19
–22 Particularly, the study of the cure reactions of epoxy composites as a function of the processing conditions is extremely critical for the analysis and design of processing operations. Surface modifications generate chemical groups on the MWNTs, which may participate in the curing reaction and affect the conversion of curing reaction. Hence, the study of curing behaviors contributes to a better knowledge of how the modified MWNTs react with the epoxy resin and of how this affects the final properties.

Since MWNTs play important role in epoxy resin, the purpose of this paper is to provide a comprehensive understanding about the effect of functionalized MWNTs on the cure behavior of the diglycidyl ether of bisphenol A (DGEBA)/2-ethyl-4-methyl imidazole (EMI-2,4) system during the whole cure process, which is valuable to provide guidance for choosing a proper set of processing parameters. To avoid agglomeration, the pristine MWNTs were first treated by acid and chemically modified using triethylene-tetramine (named as TETA-MWNTs) in the present research. The TETA-MWNTs were characterized by means of Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), Raman spectroscopy, FESEM and transmission electron microscope (TEM). In addition, the effects of TETA-MWNT on the thermal stability of epoxy resin are reported and discussed in detail.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The MWNTs produced by chemical vapor deposition (VCD) were obtained from Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co. and purified by thermal oxidation. The diameter and length ranged between 40 and 60 nm and 5 and 15 µm, respectively, and the specific surface area was 40 to 300 m2 g−1, according to the supplier’s specification. Diglycidyl ether of bisphenol A (DGEBA, the epoxy equivalent was 196 g eq−1) was obtained from Blue Star New Chemical Materials Co. Amine hardener 2-ethyl-4-methyl imidazole (EMI-2,4) was distilled under reduced pressure. Triethylene-tetramine (TETA) was dried with NaOH and then distilled before use. Dimethylbenzene (DMB) and other reagents and solvents were purchased form Shanghai Reagent Co, and distilled in vacuum prior to use.

sec.title: The introduction of carboxyl groups on MWNTs
sec.p: Initially 0.5 g MWNTs were added into 100 m: of a 3 : 1(v : v) mixture of H2SO4 (98%)/HNO3 (68%) at 40°C for 4 h to form the carboxylic acid groups on the MWNTs surface. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, the carboxylated MWNTs were filtered and washed with deionized water until pH was 7 and dried in vacuum at 80°C until the weight was stable. The carboxylated MWNTs were then obtained.

sec.title: The introduction of amino groups on MWNTs
sec.p: Next, 0.4 g of carboxylated MWNTs were stirred in 80 mL thionyl chloride (SOCl2) and 4 mL dimethylformamide (DMF) for 24 h at 70°C and the unreacted SOCl2 was removed under vacuum. Then, the products were filtered, washed with anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF), and dried under vacuum. Thus the acyl chlorination MWNTs were obtained and 0.4 g acyl chlorination MWNTs were reacted with 100 mL TETA at 120°C for 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was washed with ethanol to remove excess TETA. Finally, TETA-MWNTs were obtained after filtering and drying in a vacuum.

sec.title: Characterizations
sec.p: The FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Bruker Vector-22 FT-IR spectrometer to characterize the functionalized MWNTs.

Raman spectroscopy was performed using a JY-T64000 spectrometer on powder samples of pristine and TETA functionalized MWNTs over a scanning range of 1200–2000 cm−1 with incident laser excitation wavelength of 514.5 nm.

The TEM was performed using a Tecnai G220 transmission electron microscope. The specimen was prepared by placing a drop of ethanol solution with about 1.0% MWNTs on carbon film-coated copper grid and dried in air before observation.
The microstructures of fractured cross-sections of the composites were observed with a LEO 1550 field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) coated with conductive gold paint.

The TGA was recorded by using a TA TGA-51 to evaluate the performance of neat epoxy, MWNTs and TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites. It was carried out on the amount of 3 mg of samples, which were placed in alumina crucibles. The samples were heated from room temperature to 550°C at a heating rate of 10°C min−1, under an N2 atmosphere.

The curing process of neat epoxy, MWNTs and TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites were investigated by a TA instruments DSC 10 differential scanning calorimeter. The data were recorded with different heating rates (5, 10, 15 and 20°C/min−1) from 50 to 250°C, and the sample mass was typically 10 mg using nanotubes as the filler at a concentration of 0.5 wt.%.

sec.title: Morphologies of MWNTs
sec.p: The TEM images of the MWNTs and TETA-MWNTs are shown in Figure 1. The pristine MWNTs are aggregated in tangles due to the van der Waals forces between the MWNTs. In the case of chemical modified MWNTs, however, the agglomeration could be reduced due to the reaction of the oxidized nanotubes with TETA leads to a mixture of covalently and ionically bonded amines at the external walls and end tips. The static and electrostatic repulsion of the functional groups lead to a better dispersion of the nanotubes.

caption.p: TEM-images of (a) pristine MWNTs and (b) amino-functionalized MWNTs (TETA-MWNTs).

sec.p: Figure 2 showed the morphology of fractured of MWNTs/DGEBA and TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA composites. Figure 2(a) reveals that the raw MWNTs were curled, seriously entangled, and easy to conglomerate in bundles in the epoxy matrix. It was noticed that there were many extraction carbon nanotubes appearing at the fractured surface, which testified poor dispersibility and weak interfacial bonding between MWNTs and epoxy matrix. In order to reduce the agglomeration, a control of surface polarity and resulting interactive forces between nanotube particles and polymer matrix is needed. 23 This can be achieved by chemical functionalization of the MWNTs, enabling the formation of covalent bonds or polar interactions between polymers and MWNTs.

caption.p: FESEM micrograph of fractured surface of (a) 0.5 wt.%MWNTs/DGEBA and (b) 0.5 wt.%TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites.

sec.p: Figure 2(b) displays the fractured surface of TETA-MWNTs/epoxy composites. No extraction trace could be seen and most nanotubes were embedded and tightly held to the matrix. It can be said that the decrease in the van der Waals force between the nanotubes as well as the hydrogen bonding that may be occurred between the opened epoxide rings in the matrix and the amino groups of the surface of MWNT, contribute to the good dispersion and strong interfacial bonding in epoxy resin. The good compatibility of TETA-MWNT in epoxy matrix can improve the properties of the composites.

sec.title: FTIR spectroscopy
sec.p: The FTIR general spectra of the raw MWNTs and amino-functionalization MWNTs and cured TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA composites are shown in Figure 3. In the TETA-MWNTs spectrum (b), the significant increase at 3420 cm−1 indicates the appearance of an NH2 group. The feature at wavenumber 1500 cm−1 corresponds to the absorption of N–H bending and stretching and the C=O stretching was at 1650 cm−1. The feature at wavenumbers 3000–2800 cm−1 corresponds to C–H stretching and that at 1124 cm−1 corresponds to C–N stretching band in TETA. The IR of the spectrum (b) confirms that MWNTs was successfully modified by TETA. In spectrum (c), the disappearance of the 3415 cm−1 peak of NH2 groups and the appearance of 1033 cm−1 to the C–N+ stretching vibration indicate the reaction of the amino group at the TETA-MWNT with an epoxy group at the matrix. The amino-functionalized MWNTs are expected to have a chemical reaction with epoxy according to Figure 4.

caption.p: FTIR spectra of (a) pristine MWNTs, (b) TETA-MWNTs and (c) TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA composites.
Chemical reaction between amino-functionalized MWNTs and epoxy.

sec.title: Raman spectroscopy
sec.p: Raman spectra offer useful information concerning the slight structural changes of MWNTs, especially the changes due to significant sidewall modification. Figure 5 shows the Raman spectrum of the MWNTs and TETA-MWNTs. The characteristic peaks of the MWNTs tangential modes, namely the D band (disorder, sp 3 banding) at 1350 cm−1 and the G band (graphitic, sp 2 banded carbon) at 1580 cm−1 slightly changed because of the conjugated effect of triethylene-tetramine. As Raman scattering is strongly sensitive to the electronic structure, this result is taken as obvious evidence for the chemical functionalization.

caption.p: Raman spectra of (a) raw MWNTs and (b) TETA-MWNTs.

sec.title: Effect of TETA-MWNTs on DGEBA’s curing reaction
sec.p: In order to evaluate the effects of the TETA-MWNTs on the curing behavior of epoxy resin, a basic non-isothermal DSC dynamic scan was performed. The non-isothermal curing of neat epoxy and epoxy nanocomposites at the same heating rate 10°C min−1 are shown in Figure 6. Small low-temperature shoulder peaks are observed in curves (b) and (c), which indicate that the hydroxyl groups and amino groups on the surface of MWNTs initiate the reaction with epoxy. In addition, the shift of the DSC exothermic peaks to lower temperature was observed in the presence of TETA-MWNTs, showing that TETA-MWNTs -filled epoxy was obviously faster in reaching the exothermic peak than neat epoxy and raw MWNTs-filled epoxy. Table 1 demonstrates the effects of MWNTs and TETA-MWNTs on initial curing temperature (T i), curing peak temperature (T p) and the curing reaction heat (▵H) of all the studied systems. It can be observed that the initial temperature and the peak temperature increase with increasing the heating rate in every system. In the actual production, resins cure under a constant temperature, in other words, the heating rate equals 0°C min−1. Straight lines are fitted according to T p under different heating rates. The intercepts of the lines are gained as the actual curing peak temperatures. An obvious trend can be observed in Figure 7. The T p at the heating rate of 0°C min−1 declines with the addition of TETA-MWNTs.

caption.p: Dynamic DSC curves for (a) neat epoxy and (b) 0.5 wt.%MWNTs/DGEBA and (c) 0.5 wt.%TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites.
Relations between T p and heating rate of (a) neat epoxy and (b) 0.5 wt.%MWNTs/ DGEBA and (c) 0.5 wt.%TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites.
Initial curing temperature, peak temperature and total heat of reaction of the cured systems at the different heating rate.

sec.p: In addition, the exothermic peaks of the nanocomposites are lower than that for the neat epoxy, this has also been observed by others. 19–20,24 –26 The reason for this may be the addition of nanotubes decreased the extent of conversion of the epoxy resins. It is possibly because the existence of the nanotubes caused an increase in viscosity and physically hindered the mobility of the epoxy monomers and also affected the optimized curing ratio between DGEBA and EMI-2,4.

Kinetic analysis of the non-isothermal, resin-cured system is based on the following rate equation: 27

is a temperature-dependent reaction rate constant, f(α) is the differential conversion function which is associated with a reaction mechanism, and

is a constant heating rate. The rate constant k(T) is temperature dependent according to Arrhenius law shown in Equation (2): 28

where A is the pre-exponential factor, E a is the apparent activation energy. Combining Equation (1) with Equation (2),

It is known that cure reaction activation energy represents the potential barrier of the cure reaction. The study on the activation energy is conducive to better understanding of the cure behaviors of the MWNTs/DGEBA/EMI-2,4 systems. Therefore, the cure reaction were studied with dynamic experiments at different values of β and applied to the Kissinger method, which is given by the following equation: 29
4
ln(
β i
T
pi

AR

, i=1, 2, ... 5

where T p is the peak exothermal temperature, and E a can be calculated from the slope of the plot of
ln(β/ T p 2
)
versus
−1/R/ T P
.

In this work, the plots of
ln(β/ T p 2
)
versus
−1/R/ T P
for the neat epoxy and nanocomposites are shown in Figure 8 and the lines are fitted to calculated E a. According to the Kissinger equation, the E a values of neat epoxy, MWNTs/DGEBA and TETA-MWCNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites are 113.47, 120.20 and 101.03 kJ mol−1. In addition, it can be deduced that the E a values calculated from the Kissinger equation exhibited good reliability on describing the curing behavior of the studied systems, because the correlation coefficients (r
2 ) were all greater than 0.98. It can be observed that the addition of pure MWNTs retarded the curing reaction because of their steric hindrance. 30 The possible mechanism for MWNTs to delay the cure reactions of the epoxy resin system may be the decrease of the propagation reaction speed. With regard to MWNT/epoxy resin systems, the contents of DGEBA and EMI-2,4 were lower than those in the corresponding unfilled epoxy resin systems, which can result in decelerating the propagation reaction and extend the gel time of epoxy resin. On the other hand, MWNTs were chemical modification with TETA, the number of the generated functional groups on the surface of nanotubes increased. According to the curing mechanisms for the DGEBA/EMI-2,4 system, 31 amine groups on the surface of MWNTs can play the role of curing agents and facilitate the primary amine–epoxide reaction. The curing reaction of TETA-MWNTs with epoxy was shown in Figure 3. Therefore, it can be deduced that these amine groups can weaken the retarding effect on the cure reactions caused by MWNTs and make the values of T i and T p and E a displayed a descending tendency.

caption.p: Kissinger method plot for apparent activation energy determination of (a) neat epoxy and (b)MWNTs/DGEBA and (c) TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites.

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis
sec.p: The effect of the MWNTs on the thermal stability of epoxy was studied using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The TGA curves for neat epoxy and 0.5 wt.%MWNTs/DGEBA and 0.5 wt.%TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 under an inert atmosphere are presented in Figure 9. The results revealed that thermal degradation of the studied systems took place through a one-step process. The thermal decomposition onset temperatures (T B) and the degradation peak temperature (T max) are summarized in Table 2. From these data, it is clear that the presence of TETA-MWNTs in the epoxy system delays the degradation process, and high thermal energy is required to attain the same percentage weight loss than that required for neat epoxy and pure MWNTs-filled epoxy systems. The improved thermal stability caused by TETA-MWNTs may be attributed to its good thermal conductivity, good dispersion and strong interfacial bonding in epoxy resin, as well as their barrier effect.

caption.p: TGA curves of (a) neat epoxy and (b)MWNTs/DGEBA and (c) TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites.
Thermal decomposition onset temperatures (T B) and the degradation peak temperature (T max) of the studied system.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: MWNTs were functionalized successfully with TETA and amine groups were effectively introduced onto the MWNTs surface. The effect of surface-treated MWNTs on the cure behavior of a DGEBA/EMI-2,4 was studied with DSC. The results showed that the steric hindrance caused by raw MWNTs had the retarding effect on the cure reaction of the epoxy system, while the TETA-MWNTs act as a catalyst and facilitate the curing at the initial curing stage. The curing apparent activation energy was calculated through the Kissinger method and it was found to decrease with the addition of TETA-MWNTs.

The TGA results showed that the incorporation of TETA-MWNTs into the epoxy matrix enhanced the thermal stability of the nanocomposites. The morphology of fracture of the nanocomposites showed that TETA functionalization of MWNTs were helpful to improve the interfacial interaction between nanotubes and epoxy, and this delayed the degradation of TETA-MWNTs/DGEBA nanocomposites.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: This work was supported by a project funded by the Priority Academic Program Development of Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions and the starting fund for high-scientific study of genius No.163030062 of Nanjing Forestry University.
